required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Project Healthy Eating in Adults. A Study on the Health Effects of Fish Intake in Overweight Adults (FINS)
clinical_study.official_title: Title in Norwegian: Sunn og Frisk. En Studie av Helseeffekter av Fiskeinntak i Overvektige Voksne (FINS)

collaborator.agency: The Fisheries and Aquaculture Industry Research Fund

brief_summary.textblock: It has previously been observed that increased fish intake improves the metabolic health of overweight and obese adults, and animal protein improved metabolic health of obese rats. In this project the investigators will investigate whether increased intake of fish or meat improves metabolic health in overweight/obese adults aged 20-55 years when replacing processed food. The hypothesis is that increased intake of unprocessed fish or meat will improve metabolic health in adults as measured by glucose tolerance, lipid metabolism and inflammatory markers.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in metabolic status (glucose, lipids, inflammation)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and end of intervention (12 weeks)
primary_outcome.description: The effects of fish intake on glucose homeostasis, lipid metabolism and inflammation will be assessed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in plasma concentrations of amino acids and their metabolites
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and end of intervention (12 weeks)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in plasma concentrations of vitamins
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and end of intervention (12 weeks)

arm_group.description: Participants will eat 150g salmon for dinner, 3 times per week for 12 weeks
Participants will eat 150g cod for dinner, 3 times per week for 12 weeks
Participants will eat 150g mixed meat for dinner, 3 times per week for 12 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- BMI > 27
- 20-55 years
- healthy
Exclusion Criteria:
- diagnosed diseases such as diabetes, CVD, intestinal diseases, arthritis
- prescription medications affecting the metabolism of glucose, lipids or the immune system
- use of supplements containing long chain n-3 fatty acids
- high intake of fish
- food allergy
